column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity|identifier|value
#Text=# Integrated multimodal artificial intelligence framework for healthcare applications
#Text=
#Text=This repository contains the code to replicate the data processing, modeling and reporting of our Holistic AI in Medicine (HAIM) in Nature's NPJ Digital Medicine.
#Text=[Soenksen, L.R., Ma, Y., Zeng, C. et al.
#Text=Integrated multimodal artificial intelligence framework for healthcare applications. npj Digit.
#Text=
#Text=## Authors:
#Text=Luis R.
#Text=Soenksen, Yu Ma, Cynthia Zeng, Léonard Boussioux, Kimberly Villalobos Carballo, Liangyuan Na, Holly M.
#Text=Wiberg, Michael L.
#Text=Li, Ignacio Fuentes, Dimitris Bertsimas
#Text=
#Text=Artificial intelligence (AI) systems hold great promise to improve healthcare over the next decades.

#Text=Specifically, AI systems leveraging multiple data sources and input modalities are poised to become a viable method to deliver more accurate results and deployable pipelines across a wide range of applications.
#Text=In this work, we propose and evaluate a unified Holistic AI in Medicine (HAIM) framework to facilitate the generation and testing of AI systems that leverage multimodal inputs.
#Text=Our approach uses generalizable data pre-processing and machine learning modeling stages that can be readily adapted for research and deployment in healthcare environments.

#Text=We evaluate our HAIM framework by training and characterizing 14,324 independent models based on HAIM-MIMIC-MM, a multimodal clinical database (N=34,537 samples) containing 7,279 unique hospitalizations and 6,485 patients, spanning all possible input combinations of 4 data modalities (i.e., tabular, time-series, text, and images), 11 unique data sources and 12 predictive tasks.

#Text=We show that this framework can consistently and robustly produce models that outperform similar single-source approaches across various healthcare demonstrations (by 6-33%), including 10 distinct chest pathology diagnoses, along with length-of-stay and 48-hour mortality predictions.

#Text=We also quantify the contribution of each modality and data source using Shapley values, which demonstrates the heterogeneity in data modality importance and the necessity of multimodal inputs across different healthcare-relevant tasks.

#Text=The generalizable properties and flexibility of our Holistic AI in Medicine (HAIM) framework could offer a promising pathway for future multimodal predictive systems in clinical and operational healthcare settings.
#Text=
#Text=## Code
#Text=
#Text=The code uses Python3.6.9 and is separated into four sections:
#Text=
#Text=0 - Software Package requirement
#Text=
#Text=1 - Data Preprocessing.

#Text=Noteevents.csv are public and available for download at Physionet.org; however, other "NOTES" data requires pre-release direct permission from Physionet.org for download as "discharge notes", "radiology notes", "ECG notes" and "ECHO notes" are not yet publicly released for MIMIC-IV as of Sep 2022, these files are: ds_icustay.csv, ecg_icustay.csv, echo_icustay.csv, rad_icustay.csv).
#Text=To run our code without them just comment import and usage of these notes.
#Text=
#Text=2 - Modeling of our three tasks: mortality prediction, length of stay prediction, chest pathology classification
#Text=
#Text=3 - Result Generating: Including reporting of the AUROC, AUPRC, F1 scores, as well as code to generate the plots reported in the paper.
#Text=Please be advised that sufficient RAM or cluster access to parallel processing is needed to run these experiments.
#Text=
#Text=### UPDATE (Jan. 6, 2023)
#Text=The radiology and the discharge notes for MIMIC-IV have been officially released on:
#Text=https://physionet.org/content/mimic-iv-note/2.2/note/#files-panel
#Text=
#Text=### UPDATE (Jun. 12, 2023)

#Text=For the publication, our team generated the file 'mimic-cxr-2.0.0-jpeg-txt.csv' by compiling an early-release version of participant notes and text from the images in CXR corresponding to MIMIC-IV.
#Text=We wanted to add these to this repository, but the data policy from PhysioNet.org states we cannot directly share this compiled data via Git Hub.
#Text=Physionet is the only one with permission to do so or subsets of the data.
#Text=This means users need to generate their own mimic-cxr-2.0.0-jpeg-txt.csv based on the released notes and CXR files from Physionet.org once all notes are released.
#Text=The dataset structure can be inferred from the code.
#Text=As of June 12, 2023, Physionet has not fully released these notes, but it is likely they are planning to do so as part of their full release of MIMIC-IV.
#Text=We are very sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.
